body.p: According to the website nationalbikeregistry.com, at the campus of UC Berkeley 12% of registered bicycles are stolen each year. Suppose a random sample of 160 registered bicycles at UC Berkeley is selected. Let the random variable X be the number of bicycles that were stolen in the past year. What are the values of the parameters for the binomial random variable X?

response.feedback: Correct. X is a binomial random variable from an experiment with 160 independent trials, in this case 160 bicycles.

body.p: In Texas, 30% of parolees from prison return to prison within 3 years. Suppose 15 prisoners are released from a Texas prison on parole. Assume that whether or not one prisoner returns to prison is independent of whether any of the others return to prison. Let the random variable X be the number of parolees out of 15 that return to prison within 3 years. What are the values of the parameters for the binomial random variable X?

response.feedback: Correct. X is a binomial random variable from an experiment with 15 independent trials, in this case 15 released prisoners (parolees).
Incorrect. Recall that n is the number of independent trials, in this case the number of released prisoners (parolees).
Correct. X is a binomial random variable from an experiment with a probability of "success" (returning to prison) for parolees of 0.30.
Correct. X is a binomial random variable from an experiment with a probability of "success" (returning to prison) for parolees of 0.30.
Incorrect. Recall that p is the probability of "success" (returning to prison) for parolees.

response.feedback: Correct. X is a binomial random variable from an experiment with 15 independent trials, in this case 200 births.
Incorrect. Recall that n is the number of independent trials, in this case the number of births.
Correct. X is a binomial random variable from an experiment with a probability of "success" (Cesarean birth) of 0.33.
